commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot planned to be made only prints out a logo.

Let's implement the backbone of the chatbot that will be built upon later.

For the chatbot to perform its purpose as a to-do list, it must be able to record data.

Let's implement that list functionality before further development.

To create a functional to-do list, the chatbot needs to alter the status of entries in the list.

Let's implement a basic "completed" toggle for the chatbot before advancing to more complex functions.

To increase the functionalities of the chatbot to-do list, extra information needs to be present in each entry.

Let's start by adding extra types of tasks for more nuance.

To make sure the program works as intended, checks need to be made to the program.

Let's implement an automated testing system to simplify the checking process.

In order for the todo list bot to function as desired, it needs to check for any potential errors.

Lets implement some of these errors to improve user experience.

The todo list bot needs to be able to remove tasks that the user does not want.
Let's implement this with a delete function.

To further improve the todo list bot, it needs to be able to store the list permanently.
Let's implement this saving function.

To further improve the sophistication of the to-do list chatbot, it should be able to automatically interpret certain inputs for the convenience of users.
Let's implement a preliminary version with date detection.

To make the todo list chatbot more modular and easier to understand, reformatting the project with more object-oriented principles may help.
Lets implement this by reforming the chatbot with new classes.

To further assist with understanding the different components of the chatbot, files can be divided into packages grouped based on their purpose.
Let's implement this in the chatbot project.

To help make some tasks in the project easier, gradle can be added to automate some of the tasks.
Let's add gradle to the project.

To make sure the methods are working as designed, test cases need to be added.
Let's implement these with the newly added Gradle functionalities.

To facilitate an easier coding experience, descriptors need to be added to each method so that others know what they are for.
Let's implement this with Javadoc.

To make the chatbot even more robust, more functionalities need to be
added.

Let's start by implementing a "find" function.

To transition to a more sophisticated chatbot, our Duke needs to be more
user friendly.
Let's start by implementing the backbone of a new GUI.

To further implement a sophisticated GUI, more features need to be added.

Let's start by beginning the replacement of the existing UI with GUI.

As the Javafx library is encountering numerous issues, steps need to be
taken to ensure that it works correctly.

Let's attempt to address them.

There still are some issues with the integration of JavaFX into the Duke
chatbot.
Let's fix these issues and integrate JavaFX formally into Duke.

To fully make the Duke chatbot sophisticated, a complete, functional GUI
needs to be added.
Let's implement this with JavaFX and FXML, ensuring that it is
completely integrated with the existing functionalities.

To ensure the chatbot works as intended, checks need to be added to make
sure invariants are not broken.

As a start to the checking process, let's implement some preliminary
assertion checks at key points of the program.

To further cement the uniqueness of this chatbot, personality is needed
in its messages and name.

Let's finalize the first version of the personality implementation,
together with all past personality additions, by changing the name
of the bot formally to "Skylar".

To further polish up the Skylar chatbot, the readibility of the code
is important for further iterations.

Let's improve readibility by improving code quality.

To check to ensure that invariants are preserved, more assertions need
to be made.

Let's implement these assertions in the event classes.
